4DCCB8C9E6684D8FBE611C3C83374EC7.description: Know that substances can be classified as acid or alkali and that acidity can be measured.

C876BCFFA7B74E68891EA53D18D938F1.description: Understand that changing some materials makes them more or less suitable for their purposes.

66A8A55324184AE1978499DAE21989E8.description: Explain that some changes result in the formation of new materials, and that this kind of change is not usually reversible.

C2AB87AE33BA46F194E3727A7571B702.description: Use knowledge of solids, liquids and gases to decide how mixtures might be separated, including through filtering, sieving and evaporating.

E54ED28724B3464B8F6EA93B8CC04160.description: Demonstrate that when heating, cooling, or mixing substances, the total weight of matter is conserved.

CFB8C424E36F41ADA36284F4F381C6F1.description: Demonstrate that dissolving, mixing and changes of state are reversible changes.

218870A026FA4BFFBDACA6EDD60A8F9E.description: Know that different amounts of heating or cooling are required to bring about a change of state.

3C7000349BCF43F88FB614D83976EA2E.description: Know that some materials will dissolve in liquid to form a solution, and describe how to recover a substance from a solution.

36AEDF3B66E24CDE819080A1A4310F1B.description: Give reasons, based on evidence from comparative and fair tests, for the particular uses of everyday materials, including metals, wood and plastic.

71945B09B28F4EF491766A47AAB181A7.description: Compare and group together everyday materials on the basis of their properties, including their hardness, solubility, transparency, conductivity (electrical and thermal), and response to magnets.

D0DD7276352E4213AEA2A0EB31B29DFA.description: Identify evidence from patterns in rock formations and fossils in rock layers to support an explanation for changes in a landscape over time.

4B5EF5FC9F9A462AA46237F1AE3A699C.description: Know that patterns of stars in constellations stay the same.

93E180FE74694E13A67E5E7D27A4046A.description: Understand that the differences in apparent brightness of the sun compared to other stars is due to their relative distances from Earth.

13A8D38C4B554EB888ABDD007F759F78.description: Describe the movement of the Earth, and other planets, relative to the Sun in the solar system

F7C593BE033C466CB2348DD3E2C6BD43.description: Describe the movement of the moon relative to the Earth and identify the phases of the moon.

6CA46A9EA8ED42789FB022EC3AB682A8.description: Identify patterns of daily changes in length and direction of shadows, day and night, and the seasonal appearance of some stars in the night sky.

B993869369B94206983E1030461EAC73.description: Use the idea of the Earth’s rotation to explain day and night and the apparent movement of the sun across the sky.

9CE5BBD54D204EEE832419928065BD0C.description: Explore how individual communities use science ideas to protect the Earth’s resources and environment.

EC7C1165B361480C8A314EC8342D3235.description: Understand how the Earth meets the conditions for sustaining human life.

5A9B7A115F0146D297FE04B13A362CAB.description: Compare solutions to reduce the impacts of natural Earth processes on humans.

68BD3766988945E995D98ACF0EAE77C8.description: Understand the effects of weathering and erosion by water, ice, wind, or vegetation.

A742C9244C034965B803655DDB81647F.description: Interpret data from maps to describe patterns of Earth’s features.

1D0FD6E75D9149D882DC646DB798BAAF.description: Analyse the percentages of water and freshwater in various reservoirs to understand the distribution of water on Earth.

A26A4688D2584C4F9A24069CEE0F6FD7.description: Describe ways the geosphere, biosphere, hydrosphere, and/or atmosphere interact.

015C8A10255742F69FF1D915B6C7D33B.description: Explain how the speed of an object is related to the energy of that object.

658E5FC90E754C5D88579A864AAE8C50.description: Know that chemical, electricity and movement (kinetic) are stores of energy.

298C6E4B30304296AB60864B0B15F75B.description: Know that conductors and insulators affect the rate of heat energy transfer.

02CBC06876EF46468B9B0DF21B6F1735.description: Recognise that some mechanisms, including levers, pulleys and gears, allow a smaller force to have a greater effect.

6F2714AD1C9F4A38921271218F982BCB.description: Make observations to provide evidence that energy can be transferred from place to place by sound, light, heat, and electric currents.

371C3918965F4959B3A2AFF708D838B3.description: Ask questions and predict outcomes about the changes in energy that occur when objects collide.

99A9723B2FCF459DAF70E5F8F1A268E4.description: Obtain and combine information to describe that energy and fuels are derived from natural resources and their uses affect the environment.

DD627DF7677E48A189C2B2CE92F5DDFB.description: Know that different appliances consume different amounts of energy to do different tasks.

2BCED7D88304453EBE4CE53E4E0F8179.description: Know that white light is a mixture of all of the colours in the visible spectrum

1AA9B6A38FDC4A259B0D83E2C66D463E.description: Use the idea that light travels in straight lines to explain why shadows have the same shape as the objects that cast them.

54132A2E5A944D26BB5082F30BD4F4F9.description: Explain that we see things because light travels from light sources to our eyes or from light sources to objects and then to our eyes.

8C4B2DAE69314FE381679CA25C7C0539.description: Use the idea that light travels in straight lines to explain that objects are seen because they give out or reflect light into the eye.

8D4C1CE9DBC140AF960F4CAB6D83AC2E.description: Recognise that light appears to travel in straight lines.

D91A352CF2BD4D6FAA5744EDE085A74A.description: Compare multiple solutions that use patterns to transfer information.

B46B91EA6A044BA8A0272C99D4FD4A49.description: Develop a model of waves to show patterns in amplitude and wavelength.

7FB1562CEC9F4419B6BBEA24A1F5EDCF.description: Compare and give reasons for variations in how components function, including the brightness of bulbs, the loudness of buzzers and the on/off position of switches.

6186F5B58BEB4B5A9B9FCCC61D7D4428.description: Associate the brightness of a lamp or the volume of a buzzer with the number and voltage of cells used in the circuit.

EC9DE5A0A0064B6289E824EA49F5AE17.description: Draw and construct series and parallel circuits.

1CE06C0E05184B049A852CF3229F5EA1.description: Use recognised symbols when representing a simple circuit in a diagram.

5A13888A2A4C4E4FB3AA734714518F79.description: Make observations and/or measurements of an object’s motion to provide evidence that a pattern can be used to predict future motion.

AFB681BD595F46B99900765F63DE963F.description: Plan and conduct an investigation to provide evidence of the effects of balanced and unbalanced forces on the motion of an object.

8F3764AF24094564A5538C3DD4E68346.description: Know the five possible efffects forces can have.

F578C8BDF5584B2EA3AD4D888937FB7D.description: Explain that unsupported objects fall towards the Earth because of the force of gravity acting between the Earth and the falling object.

38D3F8789FDF4406BB6A65B48326004C.description: Measure forces using a Newton meter.

DAE92AC8C8714F47BF8725869810CD0E.description: Identify the effects of air resistance, water resistance and friction, that act between moving surfaces

EE268D34C5B34388866FBEDD524C9BB9.description: Know that a fulcrum provides a pivot point.

580004EDBEE9469AA04EE93CB3CEC820.description: Recognise that living things have changed over time and that fossils provide information about living things that inhabited the Earth millions of years ago.

89FE51127C1940C981CEEE737B2FE033.description: Identify how animals and plants are adapted to suit their environment in different ways and that adaptation may lead to evolution.

4B5C74815FA74FC5AACDC89B2813690A.description: Recognise that living things produce offspring of the same kind, but normally offspring vary and are not identical to their parents.

04834A1DB0E546BF811AE0C20EEE1172.description: Know the names of different types of consumers and the different levels within a food chain

3A8C2274E51C46CC89ABCAB412BA43E2.description: Predict the outcome of disruption to a food chain.

C79D805701F540D3BE58FEE91E506284.description: Understand the consequences of imbalance in an ecosystem.

B20332BD7218444D811A0415DDC2695B.description: Describe how living things are classified into broad groups according to common observable characteristics and based on similarities and differences, including microorganisms, plants and animals

F9379A222A8E4B58B251D9D5BF0BED1C.description: Know the seven characteristics which define living things.

DAC7F1DCC12548B4B76BAE04F3A8280A.description: Describe the life process of reproduction in some plants and animals.

DF02C63061C848E0A60D25B4643922F7.description: Describe the differences in the life cycles of a mammal, an amphibian, an insect and a bird.

C15BA76E7460405887CD135A0FE50FB8.description: Describe the changes as humans develop to old age.

04EB1B7F02AC4FB6A2B0D307F806C83C.description: Describe the ways in which nutrients and water are transported within animals, including humans.

683620CBB4824C30AEE65E77F16DFFE8.description: Identify and name the main parts of the human circulatory system, and describe the functions of the heart, blood vessels and blood.

BF0E462C46DF41519D65698125088576.description: Recognise the impact of diet, exercise, drugs and lifestyle on the way human bodies function.

1983A713257C41E1869F4E23493285E7.description: Know the functions of the major internal and external parts of the human body.

008A17EFE90B482687D188E36F108FF4.description: Describe the life process of reproduction in some plants (and animals, including humans).

1B8E68B02C4E4203A3200EEF85786E9E.description: Know that photosynthesis requires carbon dioxide and results in the excretion of oxygen.

9263312294E6404DA75B78A95E2154DC.description: Plan and carry out fair tests in which variables are controlled and failure points are considered to identify aspects of a model or prototype that can be improved.

DDD208D39E374945B73B2131D35D7531.description: Generate and compare multiple possible solutions to a problem based on how well each is likely to meet the criteria and constraints of the problem.

2F933E9D263A4133BA69D1C91EACBCF6.description: Define a simple design problem reflecting a need or a want that includes specified criteria for success and constraints on materials, time, or cost.

0C64C0979D8B4377BB2F16EF3E05D712.description: Read, spell and pronounce grade-appropraite scientific vocabulary correctly.

EA9E5BD7EA8F48F8B5F0169E4D44555A.description: Use scientific langauge to report conclusions, causal relationships and explanations of degree of trust in results in a format suitable for the intended audience.

0127D58EBF0344BC9789D40D33EB150D.description:
Identify scientific evidence that can be used to support or 
refute ideas or arguments in order to draw conclusions and answer questions.

8956AB5F27BB49259C88D893AC5404E9.description: Evaluate the fairness of an investigation and suggest improvements to procedures.

DA2E9BAAC3BA4016BB78C8CECA51A04D.description: Use their results to make predictions and idenitfy where further tests might be needed.

BBF4BFCA6D9E43E896A2C75E0CAC3EE7.description: Look for different causal relationships in data and identify evidence that supports or refutes ideas.

65C8DA794ED04235AF41BD0FCFB305A6.description:
Decide how to record data and results from a choice of familiar approaches.

For example: scientific diagrams, labels, classification keys, tables, scatter graphs, bar and line graphs.

154B1A9577204417A1E003361025DCBA.description: Use and develop keys and other informationrecords to idenitfy, classify and describe living things and materials, and idenitfy patterns that might be found in the natural environment.

E938D84FC9E647B39BDB2489C6294285.description: Choose the most appropriate equipment to take measurements with increasing precision and take repeat measurements where appropriate.

3330DFCC70AD4B72A2D04F5DC5BE7C2D.description: Decide what observations and measurements to make and how long to make them for.

83AB57D09A2E46E8A302029093603E62.description: Develop models that represent scientific ideas and explanations including diagrams, drawings, physical replicas, mathematical representations, analogies and computer simulations.

02BC2C7168334953BCA2D8F07D3002E9.description:
Make preditictions using scientific knowledge and 
understanding.

835C9BA520964AA4BD7A3A8432F373D8.description: Recognise which secondary sources will be most useful to research ideas and begin to separate opinion from fact.

FF274DAFD6944B57A0D8C1A9281ED8C8.description: Recognise when and how to set up fair tests and explain which variables need to be controlled and why.

1C303F3B361244F3AF32C6CDDCDE6AD9.description:
Independently plan and set up different types of practical enquiry:

4.1 Plan and set up an observation over time to answer a question.
4.2 Plan and set up an observation or test to classify. 
4.3 Plan and set up a pattern seeking enquiry to answer a question. 
4.4 Plan and set up a comparative or fair test to answer a question.

22002B27B53A455389C0866F3B5222C6.description: Talk about how scientific ideas have developed over time.

76D5488E389C4CF0A94FC7B065FC513B.description: Select the most appropriate type of scientific enquiry to use to answer questions.

023CDB68F36449DE8C7C55D79417FDC1.description: Explore ideas and ask different kinds of scientific questions.
